metadata.title: Rational perioperative utilization and management during the COVID-19 pandemic

body_text.text: In response to broad calls to curtail elective surgical procedures from multiple societies including the American College of Surgeons3, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) released recommendations to “limit all non-essential planned surgeries and procedures… until further notice.”4 Unfortunately, the duration of time needed for surge capacity planning for US hospitals is unclear, with some reports suggest an outbreak duration of 12-18 months under “worst case scenario” conditions5. While a blanket policy to restrict non-essential surgery is appropriate for acute outbreak conditions, this may need to be modified if the pandemic continues for a prolonged duration, as a long wait for elective surgery could begin to result in harm for some patients. Therefore, it is essential to begin to gain a more nuanced understanding of the basic epidemiology of elective surgery in the US, as well as the burden of these surgeries on acute healthcare utilization in the US. These data are vital to make evidence-based decisions to match supply and demand during prolonged pandemic conditions.
body_text.section: Non-essential surgery, downstream hospital utilization, and supply/demand matching

body_text.text:
While we agree that all available medical and logistical information at an organizational level should be used, we also believe that downstream healthcare utilization from certain operations predictably impair COVID-19 surge capacity. Examining 2018 data from the Premier healthcare database during the relevant time period of the current COVID-19 pandemic (April-June), it is apparent that joint replacement, bariatric surgery, and spine surgery represent some of the most common inpatient elective procedures (Figure 1
). To gain a more nuanced understanding of the burden of elective surgeries on downstream acute care utilization, we provide an example using the joint replacement surgery population. First, examining 379,829 patients hospitalized for surgery across 667 facilities within the Premier Perspective database6 from April-June of 2018, we found that 61,889 (16%) were admitted for joint replacements, making this a very common operation. Second, considerable downstream hospital bed-days become available with a temporary moratorium on joint replacements. For example, the average length of stay following a joint replacement was almost 2 days; thus, suspending joint replacements for the 3-month period of Apr-June 2018 would translate to 123,778 hospital bed-days available for hospital surge capacity in the Premier alliance alone. Lastly, with over 75% of patients over 60 yr of age, admission to hospitals for joint replacement surgery puts such patients at risk for hospital-acquired COVID-19. Using this simple example, we can extend this logic to examine other common elective surgeries, as well as other markers of acute care utilization (intensive care unit admission, ventilator days, blood transfusion, and vasopressor utilization) to identify elective surgical procedures that may be need to be delayed to fulfill health system needs at a given time (such as ICU beds). When these data are combined with robust local outbreak modeling data, data-driven decisions on elective surgery delays can be made to match supply and demand in the setting of a prolonged pandemic.
body_text.section: Non-essential surgery, downstream hospital utilization, and supply/demand matching

body_text.text: Should pressure on critical care services, produced by increased demand in the face of limited supply, require relief, ORs can provide backup. Given the availability of ventilators, monitoring equipment, and critical care drugs, ORs can serve as a physical location for the provision of critical care. According to 2020 data from the American Hospital Association, there are currently only 69,785 adult intensive care beds (comprised of medical, surgical, cardiac, burn, and other) in US non-federal hospitals7. In addition to acute care spaces opened up through delays of non-essential surgeries, ORs can provide additional physical space for the care of critically ill patients.

While the idea of using ORs (both in hospitals and ambulatory surgery centers) for additional hospital capacity is no longer a novel suggestion, given worldwide implementation of this concept during the COVID-19 pandemic, specific considerations are necessary. First, appropriate staffing models need to be employed for care of critically ill patients within ORs; given delays in elective surgery, the workforce of perioperative clinicians will likely be available. Thankfully, the daily tasks of anaesthesiologists and nurse anaesthetists include ventilator management, sedation, and haemodynamic management, all of which are essential for the management of critically ill patients. Given the debate surrounding shortages in intensivists8 and concerns about a further loss of providers through illness, anaesthesia professionals can be used to build surge capacity. Second, appropriate organizational principles to manage this “critical care extension” and educational outreach will need to occur as soon as possible. To accomplish this goal, existing models, including a model endorsed by the Society of Critical Care Medicine (SCCM), could be implemented rapidly9. In the SCCM model, a board certified intensivist will always be available for consultation (either in person or virtually) to on-the-ground healthcare providers. Leveraging existing SCCM educational materials for healthcare providers (such as their Fundamental Critical Care Support series) can be used to bridge knowledge gaps. Lastly, appropriate patient types must be carefully selected for critical care management in ORs. Critical illness as a result of COVID-19 has the potential to directly affect available critical care space for other common critical illnesses (such as severe sepsis, pneumonia, decompensated heart failure, surgical critical illness, and trauma). The latter conditions are likely to either stay the same in terms of incidence, or increase given disruptions in the supply of caregivers, medications, and equipment. Care for these patients within the perioperative infrastructure may be needed if traditional critical care units (given their availability of negative pressure rooms and specialized staff) are needed to care for critically ill COVID-19 patients.

We provide a framework for actionable next steps to prepare perioperative teams for a surge of critically ill patients as a result of COVID-19 (Table 1
). As we have shown in the above example using elective joint replacements, we advocate building a robust understanding of the impact of individual non-elective surgeries on healthcare utilization, using population-based national data. We advocate using currently available epidemiologic outbreak models at the state and county levels to match critical care supply to demand using data-driven strategies rather than blanket policies in the case of a prolonged pandemic. We suggest detailed planning at the health system level (taking into account local organizational factors) to leverage ORs and OR personnel to care for critically ill patients. Important considerations include: 1) What types of critically ill patients will be cared for in perioperative spaces? 2) How will education be provided to prepare perioperative providers to care for critically ill patients? and 3) What organizational infrastructure (including intensivist consultation and regionalization of care) will work best in the local environment? Lastly, we must rigorously study the data derived from this “natural experiment” (utilization, organization, cost, outcomes, etc…) to inform health system planning for future pandemics.

Given the experience in other countries, early planning for surge capacity for critically ill COVID-19 patients is essential.10 With rational decisions regarding allocation of non-essential surgery in the US, ORs not only provide necessary physical space to care for patients, but also provide a workforce that is trained in critical care management. The time is now to start planning how we leverage the perioperative environment to allow health systems to adapt to care for the inevitable surge in critically ill COVID-19 patients.
